benchmark_details.name: Name of Thrones: Evaluating How LLMs Rank Student Names, Race, and Gender in Status Hierarchies
benchmark_details.overview: This study conducts a large-scale analysis with bootstrap standard errors of 45,000 name variations across 5 ethnicities to examine how AI-generated responses exhibit systemic name biases, investigating the effects of names on perceived competence, leadership, and economic potential.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate whether LLMs sort students into status positions based on ethnicity and gender associated with their names and to investigate the potential biases in AI assessments.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The study includes only five ethnicities and considers only two genders.

data.source: National delegates of academic and music competitions and frequently occurring names in population databases.
data.annotation: Names verified by native speakers from each cultural background.

methodology.calculation: Regression analysis to quantify the model's implicit biases based on demographic attributes.
methodology.interpretation: Higher predicted scores indicate perceived higher competence and leadership potential.
methodology.baseline_results: LLMs showed variations in predicted scores based on names, with East Asian names often ranked highest.
methodology.validation: Bootstrapping with 1,000 replications to enhance robustness.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: Names associated with different racial and gender groups showed distinct biases in the predictions.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: Anonymity of name bearers was upheld by not publishing the dataset publicly.
